Problem 1.1

The Factor Game: Generalizing Factors with Algebraic Expressions

Playing the Factor Game is a fun way to practice finding factors of whole numbers. As we play and analyze the game, we may learn some interesting things about numbers that we didn't know before.

The Factor Game

Equipment

  • several copies of the Factor Game board
  • two different colored transparent chips (Each player uses a different color)

Rules

Play as individuals or teams

  • Player A chooses a number on the game board and places their color chip on it.
  • Using a different color, Player B places chips on all the proper factors of Player A's number.
  • During the game, a number can only have one colored chip on it.
  • Player B places their colored chip on a new number. Player A places on all the factors of the new number that do not already have chips on them.
  • Players take turns choosing numbers and placing chips on factors.
  • If a player chooses a number with no available factors, that player loses their current turn. The player does not get to keep the number chosen.
  • The game ends when there are no numbers left with open factors.
  • Each player adds the numbers covered by their colored chips. The player with the greater total wins.

Play the game a few times, the consider what you have learned.

  • What are some observations you noticed while playing the game?

Student observations will vary. They may include the following:

  • The game is over when the numbers 1-15 are covered
  • Larger numbers with not many factors, like 25, are good moves.
  • Some numbers, like 30 and 24, have a lot of factors.
  • Odd numbers seem to have less factors.
  • Multiples of 6 seem to have a lot of factors.
• If you were Player A, what number would you choose as the first move? Explain why.

Player A will want to choose a number that only has two factorsâ€” a prime number. Then Player B will only be able to cover 1, and all other prime factors will be taken out of play. To maximize their score, Player A should chose the highest prime number less than 30, which is 29.

Note that students may have to play the game a few times before they realize the advantage of beginning with a prime number. As students first play the game, they will often say the best first move is a number with few factors. Some students will need to analyze the first moves in What If...? Situation A before they see advantages and disadvantages of certain first moves.
